Mercado Pago is scaling its financial services business in Chile and plans to launch a credit card in 2026, positioning itself to compete more directly with traditional banks.

The fintech arm of Mercado Libre has seen explosive growth in its prepaid card and digital account, now used  by millions of Chileans.

With strong adoption of installment payments without a card, a fast-growing remunerated account, and a large merchant acquiring operation built after integrating Redelcom, Mercado Pago is expanding beyond payments into credit, savings and investments.

The upcoming credit card launch marks a step toward becoming a full scale financial platform and challenging incumbents in the country.

Some nuance is missing here.

The ~13% take rate youâ€™re seeing on Mercado Libre / Mercado Pago is not just payment processing.

It includes:

â€¢ Card + QR processing
â€¢ Fraud prevention & chargeback risk (material in Argentina)
â€¢ Installments and credit underwriting
â€¢ Reconciliation, settlement, and cash management
â€¢ Seller tools and buyer protection
â€¢ Often logistics subsidies embedded in the take rate

Mercado Libre has been very explicit for years (since my days):

Payments are high-volume, low-margin, and competitive by design.
Credit is where returns on capital and earnings power actually live.

Thatâ€™s why:

â€¢ Payments margins are structurally compressible
â€¢ Credit penetration keeps increasing every quarter
â€¢ Payment economics are reinvested to defend the ecosystem

That â€œ1/7thâ€ isnâ€™t just a toll. Itâ€™s risk, infrastructure, and optionality that most vendors could never replicate on their own.

Yes, payments can be competed away. $MELI openly acknowledges this. I said dis since day one as IRO. 

But credit, logistics, trust, and scale together are the moat.

This is also why I worry more about pure payment processors than $MELI.

Payments alone trend toward zero. Ecosystems donâ€™t.

PayPal World is a new global platform announced in July 2025, partnering with NPCI to integrate UPI with systems like Venmo, Mercado Pago, and Tenpay Global. It enables seamless cross-border payments via open APIs, starting with PayPal/Venmo interoperability in fall 2025.

As a user, you benefit by using UPI to pay international merchants directly (e.g., shop US stores from India), send/receive money globally without extra fees or conversions, and access 2B+ users for easier transactions. More wallets will join soon.
